verb.description: Rest or move on or near the surface of a liquid without sinking.
examples: she relaxed, floating gently in the water

verb.description: Move or hover slowly and lightly in a liquid or the air; drift.
examples: clouds floated across a brilliant blue sky
through the open window floated the sound of traffic

verb.description: Put forward (an idea) as a suggestion or test of reactions.
(of a currency) fluctuate freely in value in accordance with supply and demand in the financial markets.
examples: a policy of letting the pound float

noun.description: A thing that is buoyant in water.
A platform mounted on a truck and carrying a display in a parade.
A hand tool with a rectangular blade used for smoothing plaster or concrete.
A soft drink with a scoop of ice cream floating in it.
(in critical path analysis) the period of time by which the duration of an activity may be extended without affecting the overall time for the process.

phrases: Kevin doesn't exactly float her boat
If that's what floats your boat, go for it, but it leads us nowhere fast.
Listen, if wearing pantyhose floats your boat and everyone is happy, good for you.
Personally, I didn't like heavy metal bands, but hey, like I always said, Whatever floats your boat and sinks your ship.
Whatever floats your boat, sweetheart, he said nonchalantly.
origin: Old English flotian (verb), of Germanic origin and related to fleet, reinforced in Middle English by Old French floter, also from Germanic.
